data.title: Gaming and Leisure Properties: The Market Is Still Undervaluing This High-Yield Casino REIT
data.description:
Introduction

The last time I covered Gaming and Leisure Properties (GLPI), I highlighted their compelling yield, strong growth pipeline, and solid AFFO despite the recent macro headwinds.

Following a solid earnings report released recently, GLPI’s Buy rating is reiterated despite the stock returning ~10% since the last coverage, as the valuation and yield continue to be attractive, standing to benefit from potential macro improvements.

Internal Developments

GLPI reported a strong Q4 and 2025 overall, beating the market’s FFO and revenue estimates by quite a bit, with a very solid AFFO of $1.12 billion in 2025 (vs. $1.06 billion in 2024) and $3.88 per share in 2025 (vs. $3.77 in 2024). Based on today’s price, that places them at a solid P/AFFO of about 12.45.

GLPI also highlighted its strong pipeline, with ~$2.65 billion worth of commitments at an average cap rate of 8.51%, while also recently finishing the acquisition of Bally's Lincoln for $700 million (primarily through debt), with an initial cap rate of 8% and a 12.5x purchase multiple of rent, expecting it to be immediately accretive, adding $56 million of initial rent, with an initial term that extends to 2039 and four 5-year renewal options.

Regarding the guidance, GLPI expects a solid AFFO of $1.207 billion to $1.222 billion in 2026, meaning between $4.06 and $4.11 per share, for a midpoint of $1.2145 billion and $4.085 per share, for a 5.28% increase per share at midpoint, which remains very solid for a REIT in this environment.

Financially, based on GLPI’s latest report, we see a solid position for a REIT, with plenty of assets that cover their liabilities well, with a slightly better level of leverage than VICI Properties (VICI), although both of them maintain a debt-to-adjusted-EBITDA target range of 5x to 5.5x.

As they show, the debt maturity schedule remains very strong, with basically nothing due in 2026 and a weighted average cost of 5.03%, with an annualized leverage of 4.6x back in Q4 2025 and still below 5x following the Bally acquisition mentioned above, within their 5x to 5.5x target.

Regarding the dividend, GLPI now trades at a yield of roughly 6.5%, meaning about $909.54 million, for a payout ratio of roughly 81.20% based on last year’s AFFO and about 74.89% based on the midpoint guidance, without taking into account future increases.

Macro Developments

Despite positive economic data pushing them lower recently, treasury yields are still high given the environment, which is not uncommon during rate hikes, but the market still has plenty of other factors to pay attention to, including the recent geopolitical pressures, worries surrounding Japan’s economic plans that can hurt US treasury yields and the dollar even more, and several other factors that have an effect on the market’s expectations.

Despite recent US data beating the market’s expectations, with a 2.2% growth in the economy in 2025 (the weakest level since 2016 excluding the pandemic), the tariff situation reignited the market’s fears, with Trump reportedly hiking them to 15% shortly after the Supreme Court ruled against the previous ones.

Meanwhile, we saw rising levels of stress and uncertainty surrounding the consumer, who is reportedly trading down even the most basic necessities such as food, while the US consumer confidence crashed recently to the weakest level since 2014, surpassing even the pandemic lows.

I mention these because REITs depend significantly on the economy, regardless of the industry they focus on. By design, these companies have to depend on external capital to develop (since they have to pay most of what they make as dividends), while the SOFR takes into account much more than just what the Fed does.

As we can see in GLPI's case, their latest debt issuance from back in August 2025 came with coupons of 5.25% ($600 million 2033 notes) and 5.75% ($700 million 2037 notes), and although this pushed their maturities significantly, these are still relatively high yields, while issuing stock still costs about 6.5% nowadays, which limits their ability to deliver significant accretion through investments, with an 8.51% weighted average cap rate they expect on their future pipeline.

Although we’re talking about a theoretically much more limited and slower growth environment (especially due to the rise of online and potential regulatory limitations), the industry is also facing the trends seen in the country’s general real estate, with the post-pandemic boom in construction now reverting due to weak occupancy rates and rising costs seen all across the board, from workforce and materials to debt.

Still, GLPI continues to have a very strong pipeline with attractive cap rates, recently highlighting their “$2.6 billion of future capital commitments poised for deployment over the next 24 months,” with mega-projects such as Bally's Lincoln and Chicago, Live! Virginia Casino & Hotel or Caesars Republic Sonoma County.

Regarding the rise of online gambling, this one seems like a very mixed topic, as studies show both the potential cannibalization threat and also an opportunity as an “extension” to the brick-and-mortar operations, depending pretty much on who funds the study. Jokes aside, iGaming can be a way for traditional operators to not only attract new people and diversify (especially the big players), but also promote their physical operations as needed, although I continue to believe that these companies should focus especially on the experience as a whole. Similarly, GLPI can also expand more into the leisure side, having the capital, size, and experience to develop there as well.

Another potential issue comes from the weak travel data, with recent US tourism data highlighting that even though global tourism spending grew by 6.7% in 2025, the US actually fell by 6% in terms of foreign visitors and 7% in international tourist spending, likely caused by all the uncertainty around politics, visas, budget issues, etc., although at the same time, domestic travel continued to recover to a new record based on recent data.

Risks Reiterated

Despite their solid position and strong growth pipeline, GLPI will always depend on the economy, and the current environment has plenty of room to get even worse, potentially affecting the company’s tenants, and worsening their ratings.

Meanwhile, a higher-for-longer rate environment remains a significant threat for GLPI, potentially limiting the results of their investments and ultimately their valuation, as the market can still find a very solid risk-adjusted yield through treasuries and “tax” the stock price.

Valuation

For GLPI’s DCF to Equity valuation, I’ll start with the estimated midpoint AFFO of $1.21 billion in 2026 (slightly below midpoint of $1.2145 billion), followed by a CAGR of 5% for the first 5 years thanks to the strong growth pipeline and potential macro improvements, followed by a CAGR of 3.5% for the subsequent 5 years and 2.5% terminal growth rate, with a discount rate of 11%, to take into account a solid margin of safety given the asset class and industry risks, with 291.76 million shares outstanding as of their Q4 report.

This way, we get to an equity value of $15.87 billion, for an intrinsic value of $54.38 per share, which is still above the current $48.06 despite using a conservative discount rate.

Conclusions

I reiterate GLPI’s Buy rating, as the company remains in a strong position, trading at an attractive valuation and paying a solid and sustainable dividend yield.

There are definitely risks to keep in mind, but the company’s performance continues to be solid despite the near-term pressure, with potential for macro improvements in the future and an overall attractive risk-reward.

data.title: Everspin Technologies: Wait For Further Retracement Before Pursuing This Pricey MRAM Specialist
data.description:
Introduction

Everspin Technologies (MRAM), a micro-cap proxy (market-cap of $250M) on the semiconductor space, has turned out to be an exceptional source of alpha for its shareholders over the past year. In a year where micro-cap stocks have generated returns of 33% (on average), and semiconductor stocks have fared around 1000bps better (on average), MRAM has trounced these respective pockets by 2.5x and 1.8x respectively!

If MRAM’s sturdy performance has managed to pique your interest, and you’re keen to better understand this story, read on to find out.

What Is The USP of Everspin Technology?

Everspin Technology, which is headquartered in Chandler, Arizona, and has a design center in Austin, Texas, isn’t your standard semiconductor company. Rather, it operates in the niche terrain of MRAM (Magnetoresistive Random Access Memory) technology, which is a small subset of the broader semiconductor memory market.

At a market size of less than $6B (which represents only around 5% of the semiconductor memory market), the global MRAM market is certainly not as prominent as traditional memory technologies such as DRAM, SRAM and NAND Flash, but the growth potential of this market (and incumbents such as Everspin) should not be played down. To elaborate, while the broader memory market will likely only grow at 7% through the next decade, the MRAM market is expected to grow at a pace of 4x more, at +30% levels!

MRAM, I feel, will see plenty of takers, as it is something of a disruptor technology that seeks to combine the best of what NAND Flash, SRAM and DRAM have to offer. What if you could have a technology that infuses the cost economics of volatile memory such as DRAM, the superior access speed of another volatile memory-SRAM, and the memory retention capabilities of non-volatile NAND? Semiconductor specialists refer to this as ‘Universal Memory’, and MRAM’s value proposition comes from its ability to harness the unique capabilities of some of the important memory sub-categories. Put simply, you’re looking at a tech that marries the performance of memory with the staying power of storage.

This seemingly all-in-one facet of MRAM’s technology, enables it to thrive an flourish in a wide array of critical applications that could be subject to high radiation, high temperature

What Is The Next Catalyst For MRAM Stock?

The most immediate major catalyst that I see for MRAM is its Q4 and FY results, that will be released on the 4th of March. What can investors expect from this event?

Firstly, the two key headline numbers to watch out for, are a revenue figure of $14.45M (which is a tad lower than the mid-point of management’s guidance of$14M-$15M), and a non-GAAP diluted EPS estimate of $0.12 (it appears that consensus is a little on the higher side, as management’s mid-point guidance only points to a figure of $0.105, which is around 13% lower).

If MRAM ends up meeting that revenue figure, it would represent the third straight quarter of YoY revenue growth (although a slower pace of only 10%, which would still be in line with the company’s historical pace of revenue growth), after 5 straight quarters of declines. The chart below suggests that MRAM’s revenue growth trajectory tends to move around in cycles (the peak can get to sturdy levels of 80%, while it can also plummet to -40% during down cycles), and we are currently somewhere in the middle.

Having said that, we believe that MRAM is on a long-term journey of reducing lumpy and volatile licensing and royalty fees (which is what mainly causes the spikes and troughs in revenue growth) to that of more consistent “product sales” oriented revenue profile (as of 9M-25 86% of MRAM’s revenue came product sales, and long-term management implied they want to get it to 90% or just 10% from nonproduct sales).

Because of the gradual shift towards product sales, investors should not be too upset to see MRAM’s gross margin profile continue to trend lower in Q4 and FY25 as a whole. For context, between FY21 and FY24, the gross margin profile contracted by over 800bps, and even as of 9M-25 there was further contraction (to the 51.3%). Investors should also keep in mind that relatively new additions (EM064LX HR and EM128LX HR) to MRAM’s PERSYST EMxxLX family would likely have seen a production ramp up in Q4-25 (ramp up costs of new products typically start at lower initial yields)

The market will also be looking to see if MRAM can continue to enhance its collection efficiency on its receivables' portfolio, which would reflect well on the quality of the cash flow that this business is generating. By quality of cash flow, I mean to say that during 9M-24 note that cash generated from receivables was quite minimal at $0.147M, with the adding back of SBC (Stock-based compensation) serving as the overwhelming source of operating cash flows. However, as of 9M-25, SBC expenses were trending lower by 14% at $4.4M and only accounted for 60% of the operating cash flow. A good chunk of the structural cash flow is coming from superior receivable collections, which stood at over $3M!

There’s potential for MRAM’s receivable turnover to continue to improve as the last time MRAM reported results, the TTM [trailing twelve month] figure was still below the long-term mean of 5.25x

Now, even if free cash flow generation in Q4 isn’t particularly striking, investors ought to consider that MRAM is a debt-free company, that is currently accumulating record levels of cash ($45M as of 9M-25), which already accounts for a lion’s share of the total asset base (56%).

If MRAM continues to build and hoard excess cash, I don’t believe conversations around a share buyback or a dividend can be put off for too long.

How Is MRAM Stock’s Current Valuation?

Given that Everspin dabbles in an emerging tech with great prospects, it’s no surprise to discover that the stock’s valuations aren’t exactly cheap. On a non-GAAP EPS basis, the stock is now priced at an elevated forward multiple of 37x, which translates to a 50% premium over the stock’s own rolling average of less than 25x!

I suppose some would argue that the 37x multiple is not necessarily prohibitive, given that MRAM is set to grow its earnings by 33% this year (which would almost imply a reasonable price-to-earnings growth ratio or PEG ratio of 1x).

To that, I would counter by saying that one could get the same cadence of earnings growth across the semiconductor industry (on average) at lower price multiples. For instance, take note of the S&P Semiconductor Select Industry Index, which is set to offer similar earnings growth of 32.3%, but can be picked up at a discounted multiple (relative to MRAM) of around 25% (28x).

Then, I earlier highlighted how Everspin’s FCF position was looking rather healthy this year; well, in absolute terms, FCF may be progressing, but relative to the stock’s market-cap we don’t believe investors are getting a great deal at this juncture. To elaborate, traditionally this is a stock that has averaged (the 5-year average) an FCF yield of over 4%; whereas, at the current market-cap, the FCF yield is only around one-fourth of its long-term average!

What Does MRAM Stock’s Technical Picture Look Like?

As noted at the start of the article, MRAM has enjoyed a great run over a 1-year time frame, but there’s no doubt that it has also experienced a loss of momentum over the past month. In late January and early February, the stock witnessed a series of lower-lows and lower-highs, dropped below its 50DMA, and has since been attempting to build an intermediate floor in recent weeks.

While I don’t see any need to turn bearish as the stock is still defending the crucial 200DMA, I do feel that prospective investors could potentially exhibit some patience and wait for more favorable risk-reward before going long.

I say this because, if you take a look at the long-term price imprints (the monthly chart) over the last 8 years and connect the peaks and troughs of the monthly close, you’ll see that MRAM has progressed higher, but within the boundaries of an ascending channel. At current levels of $11, MRAM’s proximity to its resistance of around $15 is more pronounced than that of its support (at the sub $6 levels), making the risk-reward unideal.

Another reason why prospective investors are advised to wait for further retracement is the current positioning of MRAM against other stocks from the Nasdaq Future Gen 200 (this portfolio includes MRAM and covers 200 small and micro-cap stocks that have the most valuable patent portfolios relative to their respective market-caps). Right now, MRAM’s (which has over 700+ patents) relative strength [RS] ratio, versus its peers is currently perched at a double-digit premium to its long-term average of 0.27x

Closing Thoughts

Everspin Technologies’ prowess in the high-growth MRAM memory technology space is something to behold, but I don’t believe the stock offers great value at current levels, and the risk-reward for a long position isn’t the most optimal either. Thus, I rate the stock as a hold.

data.title: Insteel Industries: Pricing Power Delivers Growth (Upgrade)
data.description:
Insteel Industries (IIIN) is navigating a choppy market as industrial developments pick up momentum with large-scale data center construction driving growth while residential construction remains relatively muted. Despite the uneven markets, Insteel may be in an appealing position for growth as it develops relationships with engineering, procurement, and construction firms developing these large-scale facilities, potentially leading to recurring business over the coming years.

In addition to this, management is reinvesting in operations to optimize production while lowering the cost to produce. Given the strengthening market dynamics, I am upgrading IIIN shares from my previous "Buy" rating to a "Strong Buy" rating with a price target of $46/share at 8.63x eFY27 EV/aEBITDA.

Insteel Industries Operational Update

Insteel’s q1’26 results were underpinned by strong selling prices and volumes offsetting input costs for materials like steel wire rods and scrap steel moving out of inventory, leading to the sequential compression of the gross margin. With steel shipments growing by 3.8% when compared to the previous year, pricing for Insteel’s concrete-enforced products likely drove the 23% year-over-year revenue in q1’26. Accordingly, average selling prices increased by 18.8%, driven by strong demand in the commercial and infrastructure markets.

Though the construction industry is presenting uneven growth dynamics, particularly for residential construction, the industrial data center market remains robust, providing a unique opportunity for Insteel to partner with engineering, procurement, and construction firms for materials sourcing. According to McKinsey, roughly $300 billion will be invested for site construction [inclusive of mechanical, electrical, and plumbing] from 2025-2030, creating a massive opportunity for durable growth over the coming years. In addition to constructing the facilities, service roads and supporting infrastructure will need to be constructed, potentially providing additional materials that Insteels can supply. In addition to this, the regionality could potentially drive residential developments to support data center operations, particularly given that sites are being considered in West Texas in the Midland Basin.

Despite the broad opportunities at hand, Insteel may be limited for growth given domestic production constraints for wire rod following two plant closures in the US. Accordingly, Nucor (NUE) and Liberty Steel each idled wire rod rolling mills in the United States as a result of challenging economics for the steel products, reducing domestic production by 800,000 tons per year, creating a wider dispersion between demand and domestic supply. This has largely pushed Insteel to augment capacity by importing wire rod, impacting gross margins due to the higher costs to import. Accordingly, this will likely continue through the remainder of eFY26, particularly given the strengthening industrial construction market environment.

Another factor that may impact Insteel’s market is Exxon Mobil’s (XOM) entrance into the building materials industry with Proxxima, a corrosion-resistant, carbon-based material designed as an alternative to rebar. Accordingly, Proxxima is 75% lighter than steel and can be installed 40% faster than steel rebar.

The Section 232 tariffs imposed in 2025 have resulted in mixed economic factors that have impacted Insteel in recent quarters. From a pricing perspective for PC strand, steel product import restrictions have resulted in stronger pricing power for Insteel, allowing the company to realize substantial price increases for its steel products. On the other hand, import restrictions have impacted material costs for domestically produced wire rod, negatively affecting Insteel’s margins.

Relating to steel tariffs, President Trump has been hinting at the possibility of rolling back certain steel product import tariffs to ease consumer inflationary pressures. This could potentially impact Insteel’s PC strand used in slab-on-grade construction for housing units, though which steel products the president is considering isn’t fully known.

Insteel Industries Financial Position

Looking ahead to eq2’26, I’m forecasting Insteel to generate $189.6 million in net revenue with a diluted EPS of $0.71/share. My forecast considers pricing dynamics for steel imports and improving operating leverage along with acquisition-related costs rolling off. Overall, I believe the market Insteel participates in is supportive of volume and pricing growth for eFY26, potentially driving another year of strong revenue generation.

Insteel closed q1’26 with 109 days of inventory on hand, up from 90 days in the prior quarter as a result of higher-cost materials going into inventory. Higher materials costs may have been, in part, impacted by tariff costs on steel product imports, which still remain at 50%. Accordingly, Insteel purchased offshore wire rod in the quarter to offset limited domestic supply.

As a result of the necessary steel imports, Insteel may experience relatively elevated inventory levels until the domestic market normalizes, which may not occur in eFY26. This may result in higher input costs for the time being, given the high import tax, shipment costs, and bulk materials imported to facilitate PC production.

Insteel closed q1’26 with $15.6 million in cash & equivalents and no debt on the balance sheet; Insteel has $100 million in available liquidity through its revolving credit facility, providing the firm substantial flexibility to continue to grow through acquisition and reinvestment going forward. As part of Insteel’s capital allocation plan for eFY26, the firm will be investing in its plants to support yields for engineered structural mesh with the intent of reducing production costs.

Risks Related to Insteel Industries

Bull Case

Large-scale data center developments may drive multiple verticals for growth, including facility construction, service roads, and potentially surrounding-area residential developments in desolate regions. Despite input cost pressures, Insteel has been successful in dynamically increasing prices for PC strand, offsetting margin risk. Reinvested capital in production may improve operating leverage over time.

Bear Case

Input costs may lead to choppy inventory management and margins for the coming quarters. Exxon’s entrance into the building materials market could potentially impact Insteel’s market long-term.

Valuation & Shareholder Value

IIIN shares are currently trading at an appealing valuation at 8.49x EV/aEBITDA, creating an appealing buying opportunity for investors seeking to enter into a position. With a growing opportunity in data center development, I believe Insteel may realize certain growth catalysts over the coming quarters, particularly as new developments accelerate. Fundamentally, I believe IIIN shares should be priced at $46/share at 8.63x eFY27 EV/aEBITDA; I am upgrading my rating to a "Strong Buy."

Using the model: the valuation table above references my financial forecast in the firm’s “financial position” section and ties it to the stock’s historical trading premiums. The trading premium array is derived through the normal operating cycle with the blue-sky scenario being the stock’s peak multiple and the gray-sky scenario being the lowest point. The target multiple aims for the midpoint, or the most likely trading range for the company’s stock. The trading multiples from there are set to a probability factor based on the likelihood of the stock trading at that premium based on its historical presence. From there, the trading multiple is tied to the probability factor to derive its relative market capitalization and relative multiple.

data.title: Cipher Digital: Pivot Proven, Re-Rating Next
data.description:
Investment Thesis

Cipher’s Digital (CIFR) actual pivot from Bitcoin (BTC-USD) mining to high-performance computing infrastructure can be easily written off as narrative engineering. The markets are full of stories about companies pivoting from a cyclical narrative to an AI narrative and since my last coverage CIFR is up 21% validating my pivot thesis. Therefore, CIFR remains a strong buy and can easily rerate as hyperscale lease cash flows replace mining volatility.

From Bitcoin Cycles to Billion-Dollar Contracts

Cipher Digital is no longer a bitcoin mining company. It has made a definitive pivot into a long-duration hyperscale-backed HPC infrastructure platform. The numbers associated with this pivot have now been achieved. The interesting thing about this time is not the narrative progression. It is the visibility of contract economics, capital structure engineering, and scale.

At the heart of this pivot is the 300 MW hyperscale facility leased to Amazon Web Services with a 15-year contract with options. The economics associated with this contract alone have $5.5 billion in expected contracted revenue with Amazon’s guarantee of base rent and operating expenses.

The economics also have a 100% NOI margin associated with the project level. That means revenue can be immediately turned into operating income before corporate overhead. This is a very different model from the mining business. The contract economics start October 2026. That means the inflection in the business will be seen in the next reporting cycles.

Barber Lake adds another 300 MW of contracted HPC capacity. The combination of Black Pearl and Barber Lake adds 600 MW of HPC capacity versus 207 MW of bitcoin mining capacity. Pro forma, 74% of operating and contracted gross capacity is now HPC. Only 26% is associated with the mining business. The progression of revenue mix is already seen in the capacity allocation.

Capital Structure: Aggressive But Structured for Scale

Furthermore, Cipher’s capital structure is consistent with a thoughtfully designed infrastructure build model. At year-end 2025, the company holds $2.7 billion in cash and equivalents versus total debt of $3.2 billion, providing a net debt position of $541 million. The $1.733 billion in 7.125% senior secured notes due 2030, issued in the name of Cipher Compute LLC, are rent amortizing and asset-specific to contracted cash flows. This debt will not be a concern in the future because it is rent-amortizing.

Furthermore, the company has issued $2.0 billion in funding for Black Pearl and $1.4 billion in funding for Barber Lake development. However, the most important part is that these are fully funded through substantial completion with project-specific, non-recourse debt and contributed equity. The convertible notes outstanding are $1.47 billion, but these will not be a concern in the future because of the growth trajectory.

Therefore, this capital structure is aggressive, yes but it is consistent with long-duration contracted revenue.

The Pipeline: 3.4 Gigawatts of Optionality

The least appreciated aspect of the situation is the pipeline capacity. The energized capacity is 807 MW, but the new projection of energization scales considerably from there. Beginning from 2026 to 2027, there will be an additional 370 MW from Ulysses, Reveille, and Stingray.

Additionally, the 3.4 GW pipeline places Cipher in the position of relevant second-tier data center infrastructure developers rather than minor players in the space. The acquisition of the 200 MW site in Ohio's Ulysses area via Ulysses further broadens geographical risk profile beyond Texas.

Construction & Execution Risk: Barber Lake Is On Schedule

The key risk in this valuation thesis is execution risk. The good news is that the construction of the Barber Lake site is reportedly on track. Concrete foundations, steel erection, and underground work are all progressing. All design milestones have been achieved thus far in line with schedule.

The company has secured 95% of long-lead-time equipment necessary for the project which helps remove supply-chain risk. The more important figure is that 100% of workforce requirements for the duration of the project have been secured. In an infrastructure play like this, workforce risk is often the biggest risk to execution. That risk seems to be removed.

The company is reportedly on track to achieve contractual early access and substantial completion milestones. As lease payments do not begin until October 2026, timeline risk is an integral component of this valuation thesis. Construction photos suggest that the project is making material progress rather than just laying groundwork for the facility. That is visible infrastructure being assembled rather than concept drawings. If timelines are adhered to, then the revenue inflection window is now deterministic.

Black Pearl Economics: Long-Duration Cash Flow Engine

The Black Pearl lease agreement with AWS is a very strong structure. The 15-year lease agreement has 3 options to extend the lease by an additional 5 years. This equates to a 30-year potential revenue visibility. AWS will guarantee the fixed rent as well as operational expense reimbursement. This is a very strong structure.

At 300 MW gross capacity and $5.5 billion in contracted revenue, this asset alone will reshape the earnings profile of Cipher. Assuming steady-state conversion at levels in-line with the project expectations, the internal return profile will have a very different look and feel from a bitcoin mining profile.

This is the inflection point. Once the Black Pearl asset is fully paying the rent, the perception will shift from a crypto-adjacent company to a hyperscale company. This will drive multiple re-rating opportunities.

Valuation: Paying Up for the Growth Curve

Currently trading at $17, CIFR is paying up for a hyper-growth infrastructure company. CIFR has a trailing sales multiple of about 27x and a forward sales multiple of about 24x, while sector medians are closer to 3x.

While these multiples appear rich on an initial glance, consensus revenue growth estimates are expected to turn sharply from 2026’s run-rate of about $228 million to nearly $1 billion in 2027 and $3 billion in 2029. As such, the current premium rapidly compresses based on expected hyperscale scale rather than current mining industry revenue.

The One Risk That Truly Matters: Execution Timing

The one critial risk I see to the investment thesis is the execution timing for Black Pearl and Barber Lake projects. Everything in this valuation hinges on these projects substantially completing and energizing within a specific timeframe. Lease payments are based on these delivery milestones. If energization is delayed by a few quarters, the entire revenue inflection, the entire leverage situation, and the entire market narrative will change in a hurry.

It is a large-scale data center build and these types of projects are not without variables outside their control, including approvals for interconnection with the electric grid, transformer deliveries, contractor sequencing, and local regulatory approvals. Even with 95% of long-lead equipment deliveries and their workforce locked in, infrastructure projects are not always linear.

Structural failure is highly unlikely but even minor slippages will put pressure on the shares due to the premium valuation. Timing is everything.

Takeaway

This is not a speculative mining play trying to understand how to play the adjacency to AI. They have hyperscale leases and they have structured them. They have a multi-year NOI growth story that fundamentally changes their nature as a public entity.

data.title: MTY Food: A FCF Powerhouse Trading At A Single-Digit Multiple With Near-Term Catalysts
data.description:
MTY Food Group (MTY:CA) (MTYFF) is a company I cover extensively, as it remains one of the larger positions in my concentrated value portfolio. Since my last coverage, it seems like the market has started to correct what I perceive to be a massive undervaluation.

At the lows set in November 2025, this once high-flying stock traded at a P/FCF below 6. A valuation that is usually assigned to companies with high debt, high cyclicality, or a challenged business model. In my opinion, MTY's model isn't broken as it keeps gushing out cash and the market is slowly starting to take notice.

Since my last write-up three months ago, the total return has been 26.40%. Now trading at a still attractive P/FCF of 7.59 and a 3.57% dividend yield, I believe it's not too late to start investing in MTY. I keep buying on a weekly basis, although not quite as aggressively as I did near the recent lows.

The company just released its Q4 results. Given the challenging macro environment, that even had a negative effect on the stronger players in the restaurant industry, MTY's results were encouraging.

By now, I believe most of you have already skimmed through the latest results. Instead of boring you with the numbers, let's focus on what I perceive to be the most important metrics for patient, long-term investors.

MTY Food Group Q4 Results

During the quarter, MTY showed positive net store growth of 19 locations. For the full year, the company grew its store count by one location. It's the first time since 2013 that MTY was able to grow its stores organically on a yearly basis. Given the challenging macro environment, I believe that's a great achievement.

Wetzel's Pretzels and Cold Stone Creamery were the main drivers, growing their store counts by 4.79% and 9.51% respectively. Since its acquisition in November 2022, MTY has grown the Wetzel's Pretzels footprint by roughly 35%. That is a CAGR of 10.52%, well above the brand's growth rate before the acquisition.

Wetzel's Pretzels has exceeded my expectations as more franchisees are willing to open up new stores. Often, these are co-branded stores opened by existing franchisees. By offering multiple brands, the stores should attract more customers and generate higher sales, while at the same time cutting down on costs. It's a win-win for both the franchisees and MTY.

By having around 90 brands to offer, there's a wide variety that franchisees can add to their existing stores. A competitive advantage that not many other players in the industry can match. On top of that, Wetzel's continues its expansion into Walmart locations.

According to the conference call, the company is in a good position to continue this positive momentum in 2026.

Is the MTY Model Broken?

MTY hasn't acquired other businesses since 2022. For most other analysts, this seems to be a sign that the model is broken. After all, the company is a serial acquirer that has completed over 50 brand acquisitions during the last 26 years. For me, cutting back on acquisitions in this environment is a sign of prudence.

Right now, we're living in extraordinary times of elevated asset prices. MTY historically paid low multiples for its acquisitions, which was the key to its success.

The company never owned the best brands in the world, but all of its banners are cash flow positive. By paying reasonable valuations and reinvesting the profits, the compounded returns have been staggering for early investors.

Asset prices tend to be cyclical. By refraining from overpriced acquisitions now, MTY is lowering its debt and will be able to act whenever better opportunities arise. Despite not acquiring new brands since 2022, the number of locations has remained roughly stable over the last few years.

System-wide sales have been flat for the last three years. Given that MTY has a history of declining store counts and declining same-store sales on an organic basis, I view this as a positive.

Despite its history of lower store counts and declining same-store sales, MTY has delivered substantially higher FCF/share over the decades. The secret lies in its cash-generative business model, as the company primarily collects royalties from its franchisees and acquires brands at attractive valuations. For me, it's the Berkshire Hathaway of restaurant royalties.

Same-store sales decreased by 1.7% during the quarter, but it didn't hurt the company's cash generation. I put special emphasis on free cash flow (FCF) and FCF/share. After all, it's the cash that a business generates that funds the dividends, buybacks, and future investments, and pays down debt.

In previous articles, I labeled MTY as the cash flow king, and the company didn't disappoint. Free cash flow came in at CA$130.62 million for the fiscal year 2025.

That's 5.3% lower than the year before, but it had to be expected. In 2024, MTY paid exceptionally low income taxes due to high impairment charges related to Papa Murphy's. If we exclude this, FCF is roughly in line with the year before.

FCF/share came in at CA$5.68 in 2025, which translates to a P/FCF of 7.30 at current prices.

Although not as cheap as it was at the end of last year, MTY remains one of the best bargains in the restaurant industry. This is especially true if we consider the debt levels, which have come down substantially over the last few years and are now approaching more reasonable levels.

Debt Levels

At the end of Q4, the company had net debt of CA$580 million, or a net debt/FCF of 4.44. It's still a bit higher than I'd like, but MTY is making great progress.

Year: 2023 2024 2025
Net Debt: (CA$ million) 701 654 580
Interest Expense: (CA$ million) 52.1 46.5 35.0

Net debt and interest expense are heading in the right direction. MTY raised its dividend by 12% this year and now distributes CA$33 million to its shareholders yearly. If we assume CA$130 million in FCF this year, it could lead to ~CA$100 million in further debt reduction this year.

At CA$480 million in net debt, I'd consider the debt levels as manageable even if the economic outlook were to worsen. This would be below the 4x net debt/FCF ratio that I consider as prudent for a highly cash generative business that is somewhat recession-resistant.

Dividend Growth at a Reasonable Price

Since its first dividend distribution 15 years ago, the payouts have risen at a CAGR of 15.08%. The current dividend yield is 3.57%.

MTY is a highly cash generative business and distributes only 25% of its FCF to shareholders. In my opinion, it's one of the safer and most promising dividend growth plays in the current environment. The hated or overlooked usually make the best investments; it's where others aren't looking that you can find real value.

Strategic Review

In a previous article, I focused extensively on a potential sale of the company. MTY confirmed that they initiated a strategic review and engaged a financial advisor to evaluate potential strategic alternatives to unlock shareholder value. Unfortunately, the CEO didn't answer any questions on the strategic review during the latest conference call.

There are rumors that a competitive bidding war between several groups is ongoing and offers may have climbed to the CA$60 per share range. If true, it would imply a 45% premium to current share prices, but it would be well below my estimate of MTY's intrinsic value, which I view as around CA$85 per share.

The ongoing strategic review reduces the risk of losing money over the short term, but it also lowers the chances of unlocking the true long-term potential of this overlooked compounder.

Conclusion

MTY had a decent Q4 and fiscal year 2025. The company keeps generating plenty of FCF while investors are waiting for news on the strategic review. Debt levels are coming down, and the business performed well in a rather challenging environment for the restaurant industry.

If the review does not end in a full sale of the company, I expect share repurchases to continue. In that case, MTY could buy back slightly more than 10% of its shares a year at current prices without the need to issue new debt.

Even if the underlying business would remain stagnant, that'd result in double-digit growth, which is great for a company that's trading at single-digit P/FCF ratios. While no investment is risk-free, I still consider MTY to be one of the better investments in today's exuberant market environment. It offers both long-term potential and a short-term catalyst to unlock shareholder value.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

data.title: Salspera Seeks $85 Million IPO On Thin Capitalization And Long Time Horizon
data.description:
A Quick Take On Salspera’s IPO Plan

Salspera, Inc. (TKVA) has filed proposed terms for an $85 million U.S. IPO, according to an S-1/A SEC registration statement.

The firm is developing a drug candidate for the treatment of pancreatic and other cancer conditions.

Salspera is thinly capitalized, has no institutional life science venture firm or strategic pharma company backing, has many years for its next milestone as a best case, is operating in a notoriously difficult treatment space, and is seeking an unreasonably high valuation at IPO.

For these reasons, my outlook on the TKVA IPO is to sell (avoid it).

Salspera Overview And Development Efforts

Cambridge, Massachusetts-based Salspera is developing a class of immunotherapy treatments for solid tumors, initially focusing on pancreatic cancer and osteosarcoma (bone cancers).

The company's lead program, called Saltikva, is “engineered to express the human gene interleukin-2, or Salmonella-IL2. The natural activity of IL-2 is to increase populations of NK and CD8+ cytotoxic T cells in tumor microenvironments as well as in the peripheral blood. Both of these cell types have the unique property of indiscriminately killing cancer cells.”

TKVA was previously granted orphan drug and fast track designations by the US FDA for the treatment of Stage IV pancreatic cancer.

The firm intends to expand its drug treatments to treat bone and gastrointestinal cancers in the future.

Management is led by Co-Founder, Chairman, and CEO Mr. Eddie Moradian, who has served as CEO of a contract research company and is currently CEO of Morwell Holding AG, and has extensive medical products industry experience.

The Chief Medical Officer is Daniel Saltzman, MD, currently Professor of Surgery and Pediatrics, Chief of the Division of Pediatric Surgery, and the A.S. Leonard Endowed Chair in Pediatric Surgery at the University of Minnesota Medical School.

Salspera’s Market & Competitors

The worldwide pancreatic cancer treatment market size was approximately $2.9 billion in 2024 and is expected to exceed $5.8 billion by 2030, according to a market research report by Grand View Research.

If achieved, this growth would represent a CAGR of 12.3% from 2025 to 2030, an elevated growth rate.

The rise in pancreatic cancer is expected to come from factors such as alcohol consumption, obesity, unhealthy lifestyles, and the general aging of the global population, resulting in reduced immune system function.

By region, North America accounted for the highest market share in 2024, at 39.3% of the total.

By treatment type, chemotherapy accounted for the highest revenue share of the market, at nearly 44% in 2024.

The chart below illustrates the historical results and projected future growth trajectory for the worldwide pancreatic cancer treatment from 2018 through 2030 by region:

The pancreatic treatment market is currently undergoing a relatively high pace of innovation, with a significant rate of M&A activity as larger firms acquire smaller biopharma companies with promising treatments early in their development stage.

Competitors with similar or alternative treatment types are included here:

  • BioNTech (BNTX)

  • Genentech (Roche)

  • Amplia Therapeutics (INNMF)

  • Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY)

  • Amgen (AMGN)

  • Corbus Pharmaceutical (CRBP)

  • Harbin Medical University

  • Novocure (NVCR)

  • BioXcel Therapeutics (BTAI)

  • Merck (MRK)

  • Exelixis (EXEL)

  • Elicio Therapeutics (ELTX)

  • Merus N.V. (MRUS)

  • Revolution Medicines (RVMD)

  • Others

Salspera’s Financial Results

The firm has recognized no revenue in the past two calendar years and has incurred R&D and SG&A expenses associated with its development efforts, typical of a trial-stage biopharma.

However, the amounts expended for R&D and G&A are extremely low for a company in development for a treatment for pancreatic cancer.

Its current Statement of Operations is shown below:

As of the end of 2025, Salspera had $728,272 in cash and $12.4 million in liabilities.

The firm appears very thinly capitalized by investors, including family members of the co-founder and CEO.

IPO Details

Salspera has filed an IPO registration statement to offer approximately 5.67 million shares of common stock at a proposed midpoint price of $15.00 per share for total gross proceeds, excluding underwriter allotments, of around $85 million.

No existing investors have indicated an interest in purchasing additional shares in the IPO.

Existing company officers and directors will be subject to the normal & customary 180-day lock-up period after the effective date of the IPO before being able to sell or transfer any shares.

The firm’s enterprise value at IPO will approximate $859 million at the proposed midpoint of the share price, which is well above the typical range for a biopharma firm at IPO.

Net tangible book value dilution per share is expected to be negative $13.93, so existing investors are being diluted rather than new investors, a highly unusual approach.

Salspera said it intends to utilize the IPO net proceeds as described below:

The only listed bookrunner of the IPO is Kingwood Capital Markets.

Management said the firm is not presently the target of any material legal actions against it.

My Thoughts About Salspera’s IPO

Salspera is seeking a very large IPO for such a small biopharma that has performed very little in terms of research or trial activity in the past two calendar years.

The company's lead program, Saltikva, is currently in the design stage for a Phase 3 trial of its efficacy in patients with Stage IV, metastatic pancreatic cancer.

Management estimates that patient recruitment could be completed within two years of initiating the study, and interim results will not be available until at least two years after study commencement.

So, there are several years' worth of time before a meaningful milestone is achieved, even assuming the best of outcomes.

While the market size and expected growth rate are expected to support demand for additional treatment innovation, the firm faces intense competition from major pharmaceutical companies with deep pockets developing their own treatment approaches.

Also, pancreatic cancer treatment has been one of the more difficult types of cancers to develop treatments for, since it so often grows undetected until it is late in its development and metastasis behavior.

The company has also said it will take advantage of the ‘smaller reporting company’ and ‘emerging growth company’ designations, which allow management to produce substantially less information for shareholders.

Many of these types of companies have performed poorly in post-IPO trading, although they have been concentrated in non-life science sectors.

The firm’s proposed valuation at IPO is also problematic. Mainline biopharma firms with well-known institutional life science venture firms and even strategic investment from major pharmaceutical companies typically command enterprise valuations at IPO of $250 million to $500 million.

Salspera’s proposed enterprise value at IPO of $859 million, given its thin capitalization, short operating history, small R&D to date, and lack of collaboration relationships with larger pharmaceutical firms, is simply unsupportable, by a long shot.

Given these factors, the TKVA IPO represents an extremely high-risk proposition at an unacceptable valuation, so my outlook on it is to sell (avoid it).

Expected IPO Pricing Date: To be announced

data.title: CAVA Group's New Restaurants Are Priced In Already
data.description:
CAVA Group (CAVA) is a rapidly-growing Mediterranean restaurant chain that’s still adding lots of new locations, but its same-store sales growth has slowed down recently. Many restaurants have been offering better deals to attract customers, and because of its competitors’ discounts, CAVA didn’t perform as well in the second half of 2025 as it did in the first half of the year. CAVA still performed better in Q4 2025 than I expected in my previous article, though. I now think CAVA will report stronger results in 2026, but it still seems like a lot of this restaurant’s growth is priced in already.

In Q4 2025, CAVA reported that its revenue rose 21.2% to $272.8 million. This was mostly because the restaurant group added new locations, because it only reported 0.5% same-store sales growth for the quarter. CAVA also reported that its adjusted EBITDA rose 2.8% to $25.8 million. So, it still looks like this restaurant group is investing most of its profits in new restaurants, and it plans to keep doing that in 2026 as well. CAVA expects to add 74 to 76 restaurants in 2026, and it had 439 restaurants at the end of 2025. So, it’s planning to increase its restaurant count by 17% in 2026.

Because CAVA is expanding its restaurant count this aggressively, I don’t think it’s appropriate to use the forward P/E ratio for this stock. I think this company’s triple-digit forward P/E is misleading. But CAVA also has a trailing price-to-sales ratio of 7, which is very high for a restaurant. So, this restaurant needs to maintain a very high growth rate to justify its current valuation. And it may not have the pricing power to raise its menu prices right now, so this growth is likely to come from new locations.

CAVA Will Limit Its Price Increases in 2026

Consumers are under pressure right now, so fast-food chains are offering value meals and other deals to consumers who are trading down. Because of this competitive environment, CAVA limited its price increases in 2025, and that’s also why it reported weaker same-store sales growth in the fourth quarter. And it plans to limit its price increases in 2026 as well. On the call, CAVA CEO Brett Schulman explained, “Additionally, in January 2026, we implemented an approximate 1.4% in-restaurant menu price adjustment, and we do not plan to take any additional price in 2026.”

At the same time, CAVA is guiding for same-store sales growth of 3% to 5% in 2026. Because it’s limiting its price increases, it will need more traffic to reach this goal. While the company did achieve 4% same-store sales growth in 2025, this was because it reported strong results in the first half of the year. So, CAVA will have to perform better than it did in the last 2 quarters to meet its guidance. Conservatively, I’d say 3% same-store sales growth in 2026 sounds more likely than a result at the top of the range.

CAVA Will Still Grow Rapidly in 2026 Even If Its Same-Store Sales Weaken

In my previous article about CAVA, I projected that its revenue would grow 18% in 2026. Again, though, this company is now calling for 17% growth in new locations at the midpoint. So, even if CAVA reports 3% same-store sales growth in 2026, it could still perform better than I expected because of the additional revenue from its new restaurants. And it also sounds like its new restaurants are reporting good results.

On the call, CFO Tricia Tolivar said, “So yes, our -- what we shared when we were on the IPO roadshow was that a new restaurant starts at about $2.3 million in AUV and grows about 10% in year 1. And in fact, over the past 2 years, we've seen those restaurants open much higher than that and experienced, in some markets, a bit of a halo around those openings.” CAVA’s guidance includes the additional revenue growth from recently-added restaurants, and the restaurants it added in 2025 and 2024 have been performing well. So, my revenue growth estimate for CAVA may have been too low, and I’d say 20% growth in 2026 sounds more likely.

The Long-Term Investment Thesis for CAVA Is Still Intact

In theory, CAVA has a stronger moat than other restaurants because there aren’t any other nationwide Mediterranean fast-casual restaurant chains. Other fast-casual restaurant chains, such as Chipotle (CMG) and Shake Shack (SHAK), have lots of direct competitors. But CAVA doesn’t have direct competitors with similar scale. This makes CAVA less vulnerable to price competition, because it’s not just competing on price. It can attract consumers who want an alternative to burger restaurants and taco shops.

So, CAVA is also attracting long-term investors who aren’t as concerned about its quarterly reports and its quarterly same-store sales growth. They’re interested in the company’s long-term growth prospects. Additionally, CAVA doesn’t just appeal to customers who want Mediterranean food. Like other fast-casual restaurants, it’s positioned as a health-food restaurant. Consumers are still interested in health food, even though they have less money to spend right now. So, CAVA could also report much stronger results if the economy improves in the second half of 2026.

Cannibalization Is a Risk Factor

If CAVA puts new restaurants too close to its older restaurants, the new restaurants could attract consumers away from the older restaurants. If this happens, CAVA’s same-store sales may fall. It doesn’t sound like cannibalization is a problem for CAVA right now, and management didn’t say anything about it on the Q4 call. But if the company adds new restaurants in neighborhoods where it already has restaurants, cannibalization could become a problem in the future.

CAVA’s Stock Price Already Reflects Its Long-Term Growth Potential

Additionally, CAVA’s long-term growth potential is already priced into its stock. After the market close on February 24, CAVA had a forward EV/sales ratio of 6.81. If you compare this valuation to other fast-casual restaurants’ valuations, CAVA looks very expensive. Sweetgreen (SG), another “slop bowl” restaurant, has a forward EV/sales of 1.27 right now. Shake Shack has a forward EV/sales of 2.86. And Chipotle has a forward EV/sales of 3.99.

Bulls might argue that a premium revenue multiple is justified because of CAVA’s high margins. CAVA is guiding for a restaurant-level profit margin of 23.7% to 24.2% in 2026, so it still has higher profit margins than other restaurants even though it’s limiting its price increases right now. But so do other fast-casual restaurants, and all of these restaurants’ margins are currently under pressure. Even high-income customers are interested in value right now, and they may trade down to restaurants that offer better deals. When a restaurant has much higher margins than its peers, that can also indicate that it’s not offering good deals to its customers.

Updated Valuation for CAVA

Like I said earlier, I still think CAVA will report higher sales growth than I expected in 2026 because it’s adding so many new locations. And this restaurant group outperformed my estimate for 2025 as well. CAVA’s full-year 2025 revenue was $1.169 billion, which was higher than my estimate of $1.156 billion. So, for fiscal 2026, I’ll project that CAVA’s revenue will rise 20% to $1.403 billion.

CAVA’s TTM EV/sales ratio of 7 is very high for a restaurant, so I’ll also project that this ratio will fall to 6 in 2026. This would give CAVA an EV of $8.418 billion. After subtracting $443 million in debt and adding back $388 million in cash, the Mediterranean restaurant group would have a market cap of $8.363 billion. CAVA also has a diluted share count of 118.4 million shares. Since it will be spending its cash flow on new restaurants, I don’t expect it to buy back stock in 2026.

So, if I divide a market cap of $8.363 billion by 118.4 million shares, I get a one-year target price of $71 per share. CAVA’s current share price is $68 per share, so my target is 4% higher than the current price.

Conclusion

It sounds like CAVA’s new restaurants are performing well. I think my previous growth estimate for this company was too low, and it could report 20% revenue growth in 2026. By limiting its menu price increases, CAVA will be able to attract more value-oriented customers. So, I think CAVA will hit its same-store sales growth target in 2026, and it will continue to add new restaurants at a rapid pace as well. But I also think that this company’s current stock price already reflects very high-growth expectations. So, I maintain my hold rating on CAVA.
